Option E says axonal terminals don't release neurotransmitters. If that were true, then all neurotransmitters would stay on the presynaptic area until they were sent elsewhere. But since they're moving the other way, E must be false.

Option G says dendrites pump neurotransmitters back. I've heard about something called "dendritic pumping," where the postsynaptic neurons might take up some neurotransmitters stored in the dendrites. This could prevent them from being released back into the presynaptic area again. That makes sense as a reason why they move this way. 

Option H mentions that the dendrites release another neurotransmitter. Wait, that sounds like a different pathway or competition. Maybe some other neurotransmitters are competing, but how does that affect the direction of movement? I'm not sure, but I think H might not be the primary reason here. 

Option J suggests that the neurotransmitter can go both ways. But the question clearly states it's unidirectional, so J is definitely not correct. 

So, putting it together, the most plausible explanation is G. The postsynaptic neurons pump neurotransmitters back into the presynaptic area to prevent overrelease.

G. The dendrites actively pump the neurotransmitter back to the axon after it has been received.

H. The neurotransmitter is present in the dendritic end of a neuron only.

J. The neurotransmitter can travel in both directions.

A. Neurotransmitter release is stimulated by electrical signals traveling towards the dendrites only.

B. The receptors for neurotransmitters are only found on the axonal terminals.

C. The neurotransmitter is present in the axonal end of a neuron only.

D. The synaptic vesicle is present inside the dendrites of a neuron.

E. The axonal terminals do not possess the machinery to release neurotransmitters.

F. The neurotransmitter degrades immediately upon release and cannot travel to the axon.

G. The dendrites actively pump the neurotransmitter back to the axon after it has been received.

H. The neurotransmitter is present in the dendritic end of a neuron only.

I. The dendrites release a different neurotransmitter that negates the effect of the axonal neurotransmitter.

J. The neurotransmitter can travel in both directions.

Answer with only a single letter. Answer:<|im_end|>

That makes sense because if the terminals don't have the necessary proteins or ion channels to release neurotransmitters, they wouldn't send them along. Without this, neurotransmitters can't enter the postsynaptic area. So E could be a good candidate. Option F says neurotransmitters degrade immediately. If they degraded, they couldn't even reach the postsynaptic regions. So F might not explain why they don't go back. Option G points out that the dendrites pump the neurotransmitters back. That sounds like a feedback mechanism, but the problem says they don't go backward, so G is unlikely. Option H suggests the dendrites release another neurotransmitter. Again, that would push the signal forward, conflicting with the observation. Option J claims the axon terminals release different neurotransmitters. No, the question clearly states the axon releases neurotransmitters to the postsynaptic areas. So J is incorrect. Finally, option I says the axon terminals release both ways. That's contradictory because we know they only go one way. Option J was ruled out earlier as well. So putting it all together, E seems to fit best because without the terminal machinery to release neurotransmitters, they can't pass the signal further.
